translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽The Chapter about Perfumes and Water

analyzed: ukkhitta pad umiya tthera a padāna
translated: The Elder Ukkhittapadumi’s Birth Story
“In the city of Haṁsavati,
I was a garland maker then;
Having gone down to the lotus pond,
I plucked a lotus with a hundred petals.
The Victor named Padumuttara,
who had gone to the end of all things,
With a hundred thousand
peaceful-minded, noble ones,
who were free from the pollutants, pure,🔽endowed with the six deep knowledges, and meditators,
seeking my welfare,

analyzed: āgacchi mama santika  disvān aham devadeva  sa yambhum loka nāyaka
translated: came into my presence.🔽Having seen the god of gods,🔽the self-dependent, the world’s leader,
having cut the stalk of the lotus with a hundred petals,
I raised it up into the air.
If you are the Buddha, hero,
the world’s chief, the best of men,
having gone yourself,
may they hold the lotus with a hundred petals on your head.”
The great hero,
the world’s chief, the best of men,
through the Buddha’s power,
they held it on his head.
By that good deed well done,
and by my intention and aspiration,
having given up my human body,
I went to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.
I did good deeds there,
and so I am called ‘Hundred-Petal.’
Sixty leagues in length,
and thirty leagues in width.
I was Sakka, ruler of the gods,

analyzed: deva rajjam akārayi  pañca sattati khattum ca
translated: a thousand times,
and seventy-five times a wheel-turning monarch.
I have experienced extensive regional kingdoms
beyond number,
because of my own good deeds
done in the past.
Through that single lotus
I experienced perfection,🔽and I realized the Teaching
of the Buddha Gotama.
My defilements are ended,
all my existences are destroyed.
Like an elephant who has broken its bonds,
I live without defilements.
For a hundred thousand eons,🔽I worshipped that flower.
I do not recall any bad destination,
this is the fruit of the single lotus.
The four analytical knowledges,
I have done what the Buddha asked.”

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā ukkhittapadumiyo thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmai ukkhittapadumiyaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati
translated: Thus the Elder Ukkhittatapaduma recited these verses.
The Story of the Elder Ukkhittapadumi is the tenth.
The Fortieth Division: of Perfumes and Water.
The summary:
Perfume, incense, and water,
Punnāga, and a single cloth,
Phusita, and Pabhaṅkara,
a hut, and an upper robe.
Savani, and a single lotus,
the verses are all collected;
One hundred verses, and also
the forty-fourth.
